title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Though the pass of Birnam has brought the tourist into the Highlands, he has scarcely made his footing good until he has emerged from the King's Pass, the entrance to which is at Polney-gates, where the tourist cannot fail to be struck with the romantic abruptness of the overhanging rocks, the huge fragments scattered over the declivity on the right, and the richness of the foliage — the trees seeming to vie with each other in gaining a footing among the inaccessible precipices.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: There are few places of which the effect is so striking as Dunkeld when fii'st seen on emerging from the pass of Birnam.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: He would keep aloof from Birnam for weeks, judging- that I had not used him well enough, or with some light word of mine rankling in his heart, like a thorn in the flesh.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Thus, in the meantime, I was not ill-content to abide at Birnam and await the things which I knew would come to pass.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: At Birnam I had liberty to sit at ease in these sweet solitudes, and with peaceful books to while away the hours.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: So in the woods of Birnam Laurence and I walked, as we had done (it seemed a myriad of years gone) in those of Cour Chevemey.

title: May Margaret,

snippet: Laurence had extraordinary privileges  among the Little Sisters of Peace, and I, as a guest and the King's ward, still more as his friend, could do much as I chose in the house of these good women of Birnam.

title: May Margaret,

snippet: But at Birnam we dwelt in a kind of tranced peace.

title: May Margaret,

snippet: So it came about that to Birnam I went, where the house of the good Sisters of Peace looked down on the towers of the cathedral out of a kind of green silence.

title: Four years in Great Britain.
author: Colton, Calvin
snippet: At the foot of Birnam on the east, the Tay, springing out from the hills, steals along the deep glen with its black current, deepened still in its shades by the extended forests of the dark green larche, which hang and wave over its bosom, until it emerges into the Strath.

title: Four years in Great Britain.
author: Colton, Calvin
snippet: The finest and most extended view from the mountains in the vicinity of Dunkeld, is from the summit of the renowned  Birnam.

title: Four years in Great Britain.

snippet: " As I did stand my watch upon the hill, I look'd towards Birnam, and anon, methought The wood began to move."

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: According to the common story, when Macbeth heard from his spies of the coming of Malcolm Canmore's troops from Birnam with branches in their hands, he recalled the prophecy of the witches, and, despairing of holding the castle against them, deserted it and fled, pursued by Malcolm, up the opposite hill, where finding it impossible to escape, he threw himself from a precipice and was killed on the rocks below.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Birnam, a wooded hill on the bank of the Tay, is about twelve miles from Dunsinane or Dunsinnane Hill, the traditional stronghold of Macbeth the Giant, as the usurper was known to the country people.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Stewart and Beard to Birnam top — fine prospect down Tay — Craigie- bams Hills — Hermitage on the Bran Water, with a picture of Ossian — Breakfast with Dr. Stewart — Neil Gow plays ; a short, stout-built Highland figure, with his greyish e}es shed on his honest social brow — an interesting face, marking strong sense, kind openheartedness,  mixed with unmistrustiug simplicity — visit his house — ^Margaret Gow.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Friday — AValk with Mrs. Stewart and Beard to Birnam top — fine prospect down Tay — Craigieburn hills — Hermitage on the Branwater, with a picture of Ossian — Breakfast with Dr. Stewart— Neil Gow' plays — a short, stout-built, honest Highland figure, with his grayish hair shed on his honest social brow — an interesting face, marking strong sense, kind openheartedness,  mixed with unmistrusting simplicity — visit his house — Marget Gow.
